Comment 3: 
Re #2: This has been debated at length (albeit not publicly, if I remember correctly)
when we decided to introduce elisions of explicit types in the first place. We decided
that for structs it's better to have to mention the types of the individual fields
because they are probably not all the same and thus it would be harder to read such
composite literals (except for the special cases where there's perhaps only one or two
fields). And we decided that well aware that if we wanted to, we could permit and it
would be backward-compatible.

It's a conservative stance, but it has served us well so far. Call it a "deliberate
inconsistency".

This issue is about making the rules for map composites symmetric, for both keys and
values. This is in the spirit of the current approach, and is simply an oversight.
